Some patients infected with SARS‐CoV‐2 showed the increased levels of biomarkers and inflammatory cytokines related to co‐infection by bacteria, caused by dysregulation in the immune system.
33 The management of the severe form of SARS‐CoV‐2 is similar to most viral pneumonia‐causing respiratory failure. In a study carried out by Bordi et al.,
151 they detected M. pneumoniae in five patients (4.0%), while only one patient was infected with L. pneumophila and S. pneumoniae (0.8%), and mixed infections were also observed in a small number of cases. They found the importance of using a broad‐spectrum molecular diagnostic panel for rapid detection of the most common respiratory pathogens to improve evaluation and clinical management of patients with a respiratory syndrome consistent with COVID‐19.
